title: What advice would you give to an aspiring teenage writer? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sure. I’m 19 so you’re in good company. I have been writing for about six years now so I have at least a few things I could contribute with. Here are a few things I’ve picked up from a lot of trial and error since I started. Know that what you make the first 50 times will be stuff you would be embarrassed to ever see the light of day. Keep going despite this! If you stop while you suck you will suck forever.Show don’t tell. Instead of writing that someone said something angrily, describe their body movement as they say it. Don’t dictate the story to the reader, show them.Realistic dialouge does not usually use complete sentences, train yourself to write things organically. (I still slip up on that one sometimes.)You don’t need to sound Elizebethan to have something sound profound, a modern day Shakespeare would not sound like he came from the 1600s.Learn story structure! This is so important! After I took the time to learn how proper story structure works my writing evolved further in two weeks than my previous two years of fumbling around in the dark. I recommend the “story embryo”, google it. There are more things to learn like the three act structure and the heroes journey and such as well.Don’t follow these story structure models as gospel! I know I am contradicting myself a little here but the last thing we all need is another heroes journey knockoff! Learn the rules so that you can bend them later.Don’t write what you think people want to read, you will never amount to more than middle of the road this way. Write something real and that’s true to you, you need to be your creations first and biggest fan, and that is hard to achieve when you are just parroting what you think others want to hear. You are a lot more like other people than you might think so don’t think you will alienate the audience if you are honest in your depictions of your characters.Don’t call yourself an “aspiring” writer, call yourself a writer until you can stop feeling like you can’t fill those shoes.Oh and don’t create a Mary Sue, power fantasies have a place and all but there are enough of those on the market, ALL people have flaws, even the “perfect ones” and they have likely worked hard to be good people. Don’t chalk that up to just purity of heart.Lastly, you will fail, a LOT. You will have worked on something for months and it will die in your hands, I guarantee it. Learn from every failure and don’t be afraid to try again with something new while acknowledging your previous failures.I am where I am right now thanks to continuing to do this and not quitting in the face of failure, I have started and failed a large amount of projects and only now am I in a position where it might actually look like my work will see the light of day. Best of luck to you and your writing!

Wording of the question when I answered: What advice would you give to an aspiring teenage writer? Keep writing. Write every day. Writing is not a talent you receive fully formed at birth. It is a skill to be learned though practice, like playing the piano.Write to be good at it, not to be successful. At any given time, in a world of seven billion people, there are probably less than a thousand “successful” writers, where success means both widespread recognition and serious financial gain. But there are lots of ways a good writer can make an adequate living as a writer.*Write until you can make the words go together artfully to express thought the way notes go together beautifully to express music.And read everything! * I remember a conversation I had with a friend who had been my documentary cameraman and then went to Hollywood and made his living as a screenwriter. (I thought one of his scripts would receive an Academy Award nomination, but that didn’t happen.) During that same time I had written a couple of books and lots of scripts for documentaries and information videos. And we were standing around one evening sort of good-naturedly complaining that success had eluded us, when I said, “But, Jack, we’ve been able to make a living all these years without having to do any actual work.” Always remember the words of Eric Hoffer, who supported himself working on the docks as a stevedore while he was writing highly acclaimed books on philosophy. Some journalist ask him, “Isn’t writing your books hard work?” To which Hoffer replied, “It beats lifting something.”
